thread.title: Giles County banjo maker picky about pickin'
thread.title_full: Giles County banjo maker picky about pickin'

author: Robby.Korth@roanoke.com(Robby Korth)
title: Giles County banjo maker picky about pickin'
text:
Giles County banjo maker picky about pickin' Galbreath is one of a few skilled banjo makers who specialize in custom old-time banjos. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
Greg Galbreath of Buckeye Banjos in Giles County is an internationally renowned master banjo maker. His banjos feature intricate art designs, as seen below on a banjo he made for Scott Avett of North Carolina indie folk act The Avett Brothers. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
Galbreath seeks the best materials for his instruments. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
Greg Galbreath of Buckeye Banjos works on an instrument recently in his shop in Giles County. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
Galbreath designs banjos with intricate artwork. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
Buckeye Banjos is located at the base of Buckeye Mountain near Eggleston. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
A wall inside Greg Galbreath’s shop. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
Greg Galbreath and Cindy Cook play on the back porch of their home. MATT GENTRY | The Roanoke Times mg buckeye banjo 100715 
Mother of pearl used by Galbreath for banjo art inlay designs. Photo courtesy of Greg Galbreath avettbanjo1 
Scott Avett’s banjo, made by Greg Galbreath Photo courtesy of Greg Galbreath avettbanjo2 
A detail shot of Scott Avett’s banjo, made by Greg Galbreath. A brush with an Avett 
One of Greg Galbreath's most famous clients is Scott Avett of North Carolina indie folk act The Avett Brothers. 
"He was a really cool guy," Galbreath said with a grin. 
That cool guy demanded one of the most complex instruments Galbreath has ever put together. 
At first, Galbreath didn't really know who he was dealing with when he got a call from Avett in 2013. 
"I didn't really know who he was," Galbreath said. "I'd seen the Avett Brothers years back, but hadn't kept up with how big they'd gotten." 
Some quick Googling solved that issue. 
There was a flurry of emails and phone calls and two visits to Eggleston from Avett. In the end, Galbreath put in more than 100 hours of work on the instrument. 
The result was the most expensive ($4,500), most elaborately designed instrument Galbreath has ever put together. 
"I'm proud of it," Galbreath said. Posted: Sunday, October 25, 2015 12:00 am Giles County banjo maker picky about pickin' By Robby Korth robby.korth@roanoke.com (540) 381-1679 roanoke.com 
EGGLESTON — At the end of a road that goes from asphalt to gravel to dirt, Greg Galbreath crafts Appalachia’s instrument. 
Inside a homey woodshop, he’s bringing the story of an owl and mouse to life in pearl on the ebony and cherry wood that will shape a banjo.
